title: Orange paper train tickets will soon be a thing of the past
text:
Anthony Smith, chief executive Transport Focus, says smart tickets 'meet the needs of today's passengers'

Orange paper train tickets will soon become a thing of the past, as commuters turn to smart phones or contactless cards to travel.

Only half of all journeys are taken using orange-bordered tickets – down from 63 per cent last year. By comparison, the number of journeys taken using digital tickets has soared from 37 per cent a year ago to 50 per cent this year.

The move towards smart ticketing follows improvements in technology, the installation and upgrade of ticket barriers at stations and promotion of the system to passengers.

Ministers have been pushing for greater uptake of ‘tap in tap out’ payments as paper tickets are costly to produce and harmful to the environment.

The changes have saved over 684 miles of paper, according to the Rail Delivery Group, which represents the industry.

Orange train tickets will soon no longer exist as ministers have been pushing for greater uptake of 'tap in tap out' tickets on phones. The Rail Delivery Group has said the smart tickets can be used on nine in 10 routes on Britain's rail network (file image)

They said smart tickets can be used on nine in 10 routes on Britain's rail network.

They compared millions of journeys over four weeks in August to September this year to the same period last year.

The upcoming Williams Review White Paper is set to provide recommendations to 'modernise' the fares systems and bring the railway 'in line with what passengers expect in the 21st century', according to Rail Minister Chris Heaton-Harris.

The change will be 'in line with what passengers expect in the 21st century', according to Rail Minister Chris Heaton-Harris. Members of watchdog Transport Focus say Britain's fare must change to adapt to the growing number of people working part-time (file image)

Anthony Smith, chief executive Transport Focus, said: 'As the number of people working part-time rises, Britain's fares and ticketing system must adapt to suit the way we travel now - smart tickets can help meet the needs of today's passengers.

'Fundamental fares reform will help make this happen.'
description: Train journey's using e-tickets have soared from 37 per cent in 2018 to 50 per cent this year. And a transport watchdog says the ticketing 'must adapt' to more people working part-time.
authors: Daniel Martin Policy Editor For The Daily Mail
